Â Â Â Â Â  place a dot anywhere on the page. try to place it in exactly the 50% least/most predictable place

Â Â Â Â Â  sort of like a disagreement or fight, maybe in public

8.29.22  10:43 am   what are the chords on "supposed to be, whoa" in more than a dream

Â Â Â Â Â  "supposed to be" is Gmaj7 over A. "whoa" in the first chorus is generally supposed to feel like Fsus2 over A, except with bass movement. so i guess there's no point in saying it's F/A specifically, because the bass seems to wander through Fmaj pentatonic i suppose. In the last chorus, however, on the the "whoa", there's 3 chords. if you consider 3 melody notes (A, G, F) double each one a fourth above and a major 3rd above. so it's A C# D, then G B C, then F A Bb. I'm sure there were bass notes designated there also, but, on the recording, the bass seems to wander out for a bagel in that moment

8.29.22  10:35 am   why does "the ending" feel almost inside out?

Â Â Â Â Â  maybe because the part that says "the ending" is at the end of the beginning, and then it jumps to the beginning part again, at the beginning of the end

8.29.22  8:19 am   I want my electric guitar to be able to control the rotation of the earth. I've tried plugging it directly into the soil but it didn't work. How do I accomplish my goal?

Â Â Â Â Â  i think one of the apps in the Adobe suite can do it

8.29.22  7:45 am   do you think you rely a lot on the idea that concepts / objects can be blurry (have multiple traits, but not needing any of those traits), and that blurry things suggest that everything is a kind of something?

Â Â Â Â Â sure. but that doesn't negate the potential use of specificity and detail

     in other words i think you are a great musician that pushes boundaries, both lyrically, musically, and visually while remaining spectacularly average and peculiar.

Â Â Â Â Â

8.29.22  4:12 am   What do you want to be when you grow up?

Â Â Â Â Â  a consultant, to consultants

8.29.22  1:41 am   what was your most disappointing moment?

Â Â Â Â Â  whatever it was i'm sure i blocked it out of my memory

8.29.22  1:29 am   In "might quit" there's a line that goes "Hello it's a Tuesday show cause Wednesday seemed so long ago. I said it 3 or 4 songs ago"

Â Â Â Â Â that's not true. that line is from a different song

     this line stumped me for the longest time cause I couldn't quite figure out what it was referring to: the past 3 or 4 songs uploaded to your channel didn't feature anything like that, nor were they uploaded on Tuesdays.

Â Â Â Â Â i actually think all of them were uploaded on tuesday, regardless of whether you're talking about 3 or 4 before the song you mentioned, or, 3 or 4 before the song that actually contains the line you mentioned

      However, I just thought about it a different way and realised the line could've been specifically referring to *you* saying it, meaning that it'd have been either the 3rd or 4th most recent video (up to might quit's release) in which you were present yourself on a green screen, the 4th of which was "maybe i could eat blades of grass",

Â Â Â Â Â that's impossible. there is no green screen in that video. i didn't have a green screen until later. the first video i used it for was "hello sexy pants"

      a video about a show called maybe i could eat blades of grass, uploaded on a tuesday, in which you show up on a green screen and are always shown singing to the host, Damien Shmamdian.

Was this the "Tuesday show" that Might Quit was referencing? 

Â Â Â Â Â that song never references a tuesday show, but the "tuesday show" line (in another song) doesn't have to refer to anything, but, it reminds me of how i've always aspired to have a regular presentation of audio/visual content (such as a video or music video), and my preferred weekday to choose for this has typically been Tuesday, and still is

8.28.22  2:38 pm   you seem to use sus chords (both sus2 and sus4) much more than other songwriters. can you explain how you think about them/how to use them?

Â Â Â Â Â i don't think about them nor how to use them. the general experience i've had with all the notes in general is what guides me. the same way your general linguistic experience guides you through the creation of sentences...... sometimes possibly having no idea why, how, or how many times you may have used the letter...."R" for example

8.28.22  8:25 am   so i was thinking about your more recent pieces of music and now i can't decide whether i like the chill music ("more than a dream", "fly around", "if the world doesn't end" etc) or catchy music ("i'm scared", "at the corner store", your most recent song "the ending" and more). what are your thoughts on this

Â Â Â Â Â  i can't decide either, and to make matters worse there's more things i can't decide

8.27.22  7:37 pm   what do you think about accordions?

Â Â Â Â Â  they are hard to get around

8.27.22  7:21 pm   Hi i wanted to try and make a sort of breakdown of Fly Around cause I really wanted to see what you'd think of it. Okay anyway here i go wish me luck
      "i walk over the earth in special sandals
       i took those sandals off
       now i can fly around"
'Special sandals' may represent something holding you down.. It's description as "special" may be found in a less positive light than tonally suggested, or perhaps could be found rather as just a catchy verbally-'adjacent adjective' ..or perhaps entirely as just a magical item betrothed upon our main character that upon removal awakens their inner super-power of flight- I'm not entirely sure and I'd love to hear your thoughts on the line.

Â Â Â Â Â all roads lead to musical happiness. start anywhere. after writing a lot of songs, you look for the roads less traveled. perhaps i'm trying to create something extremely "prose" and then let the joys of music prove that you can musicify anything, including the proseyest things. by "prosey" i suppose i mean like not written with any expected rhythm or rhyme scheme. if you looked at the lyrics alone you probably wouldn't even assume it was a song. also the flying comes as a surprise. i'm sure i genuinely wasn't even expecting the flying by the time i'd reached "sandals." even though i'm sure i came up with the whole line just about in real time. So in other words, basically i'm just attempting to enjoy the sensation of dreaming while awake. or at least try my best to achieve that

     
      "some people wonder why the sun is not very bright"
       my arms ar e much too tired for this conversation"
I'll come back to this line momentarily!
      "i travel the distance
       in between where i was and where i would like to be a little later"
I suppose this is a long poetic way of saying I went from here to there (presumably whilst flying, of course)
      

Â Â Â Â Â i wasn't necessarily thinking of flying here. it looks like i was just continuing the same soft prosey strategy. again, i could have been as late as "was" and still had no idea exactly *when* (rhythmically) the line might end. and yet i certainly knew what the meaning of the phrase was by the time i hit "travel the distance". the rest of the line is sort of an exercise in free will to see how many times i could surprise myself with number of syllables the sentence turned out to actually have. despite already knowing from the beginning of the line what information it was going to be paraphrasing (travel from point A to point B)

     "the sky is falling"
Okay this gets interesting-

Â Â Â Â Â i think it's the least interesting part so far. sounds like it was lifted from some nursery rhyme

     in your video "gonna clean my room" the song goes that you'll clean your room after the 'sun burns out' and the 'sky falls down' so there's an interesting connection, added on top of that 'sun is not very bright' coincided with 'sun burns out.'

Â Â Â Â Â the sky and sun have been up there all my life. so they both commonly come to mind often. so that 'connection' is probably shared by a huge percentage of my songs. unless i'm deliberately trying to cut back

     And another cool thing- 'sun burns out and the sky falls down' is also pretty similar to the line from 'mount saint helens' - 'sun falls down and the sky burns out.' I suppose in general a lot of your music conveys apocalyptic emotions and references so perhaps 'sun is not ver y bright' and 'the sky is falling' were merely intuition ..but then I thought deeper.. the song as a whole... And I realized given all the present themes of the future being upon us and reconciling that with the memories of our past, maybe all this really does take place farther along upon a vast timeline, where the sun may really be slowly dying out and no longer radiates light to the extent of our own. And all this talk of the sun and skies still connects it all back to 'flying around'. His arms are supposedly too tired to talk about it, maybe from flying, or maybe even because he doesn't want to talk about it.
      "the sky is larger
       than any sky can be"
This builds on 'sky is falling" describing how unimaginably and unbelievably vast the sky truly is, presumably as seen from the perspective of one flying across it.

Â Â Â Â Â i guarantee i was not thinking about flying at this point. given the carefree attitude of this song, i'd assume that pretty much everything in here so far, including the sandals, sky, the flying, are part of a floaty collage of aesthetics here

           "oo, ah, oh, ee
      my calendar is telling me it's the future"
I remember you talking about this sorta lyrical device in an answer to a question about balancing phrases and musical non-words, and this truly masters that- the punch and impact in this chorus is really felt.

Â Â Â Â Â in addition to that technique, i also used another balancing trick on a doubled timescale here, which is where half the page is filled with words (etc), and the other half of the page just has 1 word. (future). so it sort of invokes a comparison of "everything to 1". which is an interesting ratio for those following along mathematically

           "somewhere there's a second scene
       with characters that never speak
       but you still know exactly what they mean
       and you still know exactly what the story will be"
This 'second scene' musically illustrates a depiction of characters who despite never exchanging any dialogue you still know what they are saying, the way a drawing conveys a story without any words.
      "i travel the world without my blanket
       so when i'm feeling tired
      i can just... fly around"
This is very tongue-in-cheek contradictory all around yet elicits such powerful feelings and is honestly really musically beautiful.

Â Â Â Â Â seems like a double negative is achieved in that line somehow. again probably attempting to dream while i'm awake. sometimes saying things backwards is a nice way to throw off the boring non-dreaming part of the brain. which i suppose would be the frontal lobe for those of you following along neurologically

           "most people wonder if the moon is part of the sky
       or if it's just a decoration added later"
This line retains the themes of out-of-our-world observations of the sun and skies from the previous verses upon titularly flying around. It also retains a merit of scientific accuracy given as you've said in your own words: ''holy sh*t we just got hit with another ball of flaming rocks- and it kind of made a mess. which is ðŸŽ¶now the moonðŸŽ¶.' In essence this line maybe asks the question 'is the moon really real?' And while being musically a melodic 'echo' of 'sun is not very bright'

Â Â Â Â Â i can tell you that the musical/lyrical echo is the primary reason for this line's existence. i guess it's that part of the second verse where it's time to be mildly responsible in the songwriting. it echoes the 'some people wonder', and instead of "sun" it's "moon", which felt like the standard verse 1 to 2 transferrence. and the rest of the line is just the best option i could come up with for finishing it. it also seems to generally play a 3rd above the first verse's line, (not to mention an actual harmony added above it here) which playes into the mention of 'decoration', and it is 'later' in 2 ways actually, because the this verse's line comes later than the first, but, also because the vocal singing the higher harmony here came later than the lead

      the question simultaneously implies the same feeling the statement 'the sky is larger than any sky ca n be' does.      

Â Â Â Â Â possibly true

     "oo, ah, oh, ee
       my galaxy is spinning toward the future"
Continuing to tie in visualizations of beyond-our-world intergalactic wonders, this line ties in both time and space.

Â Â Â Â Â i recall 'galaxy' being some kind of freudian slip at one point while i was running through the first bridge. so i earmarked it for the second

     
      "somewhere in the 7th scene
       when no one understands the point of view
       that you now find so familiar"
'7th scene' captures the feeling that we've moved on a little bit further into this story's future

Â Â Â Â Â true

      and also makes for a zesty rhyme with '2nd scene.' But really this line truly speaks for itself- it finds this whole analysis to be ironic. We can't fully understand the point of view that the artist finds so familiar. But that's the beauty of storytelling and songwriting.

Â Â Â Â Â i can tell you that a big part of the reason this line is built the way it is is to juggle the rhythm and surprise myself as much as possible. basically to keep the sentence going as long as possible, causing a long string of 'challenges' to the rhythm and then see if i can maneuver it into a musically and linguistically coherent landing. it's kind of like when pilots repeatedly try to damage their airplane while in flight, to challenge themselves to create increasingly more interesting landings. But, besides the rhythm and music there, the words are also describing when you get that much deeper into a story and you've developed a deeper familiarity with the story's world that those outside this story might not share

           "oh
       my memori es are coming back in ways i wasn't ready for
       but i'm still enjoying the way it feels"
This line hits right in the feels.

Â Â Â Â Â that is generally the preferred target to hit, as per company policy

      Also the 'oh' later transforms into 'oooh' later in the song- I just noticed that.

Â Â Â Â Â i'll grab any souvenir i can, for proof of not copy-pasting

           "so i'm holding onto the details
       capture this moment
       in a series of carefully chosen words and phrases
       and then replay it"
This is an interesting sorta meta realization and description of songwriting, the literal feeling of capturing a feeling.. or a memory ..or a memory being made there and then.  

Â Â Â Â Â i basically poured my heart out in the previous couple of lines, and i understood that i'd probably completely submerged myself beyond any chance of getting myself back out in any 'normal'ish way, so, ....... i sort of figured i might as well become an alien at this point...... froze the harmony on a sort of ambiguosly not-really-stable but not-really-unstable, semi-awkward place, and then rigidly went to prose to literally explain what a diligent artist surely often tries to do, in situations where they encounter an inspiring situation or moment. simply try to capture it, like a scientist would capture some kind of specimen

           "walk over the earth in special sandals
       i kick those sandals off
       and watch them fly around"
Flipp ing and twisting the opening line around and in on itself to expand upon it in a new perspective in a new verse.

Â Â Â Â Â yep, i am a flipsman all too frequently i will confess

            "i didn't notice
       if they ever landed
       but if they do i'll understand the reason"
Of course alluding to the law of gravity, but also still (purposefully or not) tying in with the other apparent 'scientific' details in this song such as the sun's dwindling illumination and the moon's decorative origins.

Â Â Â Â Â actually, i was just trying to promote unconditional understanding. "if ____ happens, i'll understand." more of a spiritual vibe here

            "oh, ah, oo, ee
       the melody is drifting into the future"
The melody literally drifts into the future in spectacular key change faction. The vocal non-words are even rearranged so you really feel that 'oo'!

Â Â Â Â Â while also eagerly taking the chance to prove i did not copy-paste

           "and i feel pretty good
       about what time it is
       about what day it ever was and how it came to this"
A feeling of content with the past and how we got here, and maybe even a glimpse of hope for the future.  
      "ooooh"
'dangmmmmmm..'
      "the memory is drifting back in ways that i'll
       pretend to know and understand
       and i pretend to know exactly how the story will end"
Myself and I'm sure so many others know this feeling, it's so human to think, feel, and perhaps hope you know what will happen next. This completes the themes of storytelling within this song- from knowing what the story will be to pretending you know how it will end. And that story stretches beyond fiction into our own personal narratives, of the past, present and future. No one else really understands that narrative. That's where art is sparked and discovered within and throughout and beyond. I really appreciate your music and what you do, thank you for the songs you write and the art you share.
      "travel the
       walk over the
       into the
       back to the"
Of course I'm sure this is self explanatory, following the previous lyric. Yes, the meaning is very immediate.
'back to the...' ...future.The true meaning of the song is back to the future. time travel through alternate realities with marty mcflie (tom holland) and doc ock

Â Â Â Â Â for me, a back to the future reference would have michael j fox instead, but, it's not a back to the future reference. these last vocals are trying to increase the chances that you will want to go back to the beginning and listen again
